page.lettertext:
fol.288r
Extract of my letter to my L. T
re
r 23 April 94
Their aunswear about
e matter of remboursement is delivered
unto me, but nothing sayed to
t
effect, as when I writte my
last
e 13 of this pres
e
t, I well hoped to have heard in regard
of a further offer of some annual satisfaction to be made unto
her
M
ty
.
For although they were in talke how somewhat
might be done, yet doubting in parte how
e contrey woulde
fourme it, and partely also how her M
ty
would accept of
a little, they grewe to no c
o
clusion. All their aunswear
in a maner, some certaine pointes excepted, is
e same
t
I
signified
e 22 of Fe
b
when I reported in like maner what
was replyed againe by me, and I know not w
at
more can be
added now unto it. Againe I am
suaded
t
nothing
will prevaille, whatsoever I say besides, because
e matter
is so fitte for replyes and rejoinders,
t
there would be no
ende of disputing upon it. That w
c
they have alleadged
of their detriments receaved by meanes of fluddes and
water breaches, I suppose to be no lesse then they seeme
to insinuat. For
e like inundations were never seene
of
e rivers and land waters in
e memory of anie. For
all
e Bettue, and B
o
mels wert, are overflowen, and a great
part of
e contry round about
Utrecht,
and
Amersfort,
in so
much as
e very gates of
e towne of Amersfort,
e suburbes
of
Vianen
, and many dorpes and villages, are caryed cleane
away, and multitudes of people, to
e nomber, it is thought,
of 3000 soules, are drowned. And
e like is reported
of
e lande about
Collen,
where
e waters are risen higher
by six foote, then hath bin hitherto knowen by any recorde,
w
c
is supposed to
ceede of
e great abondance of raine and
snow,
t
hath fallen in these and in
e upper c
o
tries: and of
e long c
o
tinuance of this boistrous winde at West, w
c
hath
forced
e rivers to swell out of measure. For there have
bin some c
o
mitted, to take particular information, of all
e
fol.288v
harme
t
hath bin done in every parte of these Provinces, and
their losses doe amount to a very great s
u
me, w
c
is a principall
cause of their slacknesse in assenting to this years c
o
tributions.
For
e Provinces doe c
o
monly passe their consents by
e Last
day of Ja
n
or immediatly upon it, and now it so falleth out,
t
onely 3 Provinces,
Holland
Utrecht and
Guelderland,
have
accorded their portions.
Where in
e knitting of their aunswear they require,
t
I
would signifie, what they had sayd by worde of mouth, and
is omitted in their writing, I take no great pleasure in telling
their tale, but yet to discharge my duety therein, this is all
t
I remember
t
resteth unsignifyed. They say they had
oftentimes debated this matter of my message, and were excee-
dingly
plexed in devising how to deale,
t
both her M
ty
might
be pleased, and their owne estate preserved: but although
they had bin busied as never so much in any other matter,
yet they founde it impossible to doe
t
w
c
was required, and
they thought very much to be pressed unto it. Wee doe all,
say they, confesse
t
wee are bound to her M
ty
next to God,
for w
c
it doth not becomme us to contest w
t
her in wordes
about
e equity of our cause, but yet to say as
e trueth is,
and every man knoweth, wee are farre from
t
tranquillitie,
whereup
o
wee c
o
cluded our Treaty w
t
her H
es
. It is also to
be shewed,
t
since
e very first year, wee could never enjoy
those forces and nombers, for w
c
wee had c
o
tracted and
pawned our townes. And
t
w
c
payneth us most, is to see
t
her H
es
doeth c
o
tinually disbourse very great s
o
mes of monie
for
e paym
e
t of her people, and yet matters are so caryed
[at] neither she nor
e c
o
try, hath
t
use of their service as in reas
o
is behoofull. For many more might be spared from the
cautionary townes and from
t
of
Ostende,
then wee could
ever obtaine by any instant intreaty: and of those
t
have
bin sent us, wee were evermore uncertaine w
at
account to make
of them, through their often revocations, and cassings, and
fol.289r
countermandes, and other doutfull messages, w
c
put us cleane
out of course of an orderly
ceeding, both for casting our plottes
and atchieving our attemptes. Againe her H
es
may rem
e
ber
t
in
e year 85 before
e Treaty was c
o
cluded, we did flattly
then refuse, as
e preface thereunto doth expresse very plainely,
to c
o
tract for a lesser nomber would but drawe our warres
at lenght, and cause
e people to dispayer, when they saw
t
their
troubles would never have an ende, whereof we looked for
no other but a soddaine c
o
position and agreem
e
t w
t
e Enemie.
All this notwithstanding, we can not at this p
nt
, nor could not
these two years bring 1000 men of her M
tys
c
o
panies to
e service
of
e fielde. These and other like speeches were deli-
vered unto me by worde of mouthe, but in very humble termes
and duetifull sorte. To make your L. partaker of my
aunswears againe, were to trouble you indiscreetly w
t
a tedious
recitall. But after I had spoken w
at
was meete for her M
tie
,
I lette them understand
t
wordes and writings were good
cheape, and
t
needes they must determine to make some other
paym
e
t. For though their state was not so good, as was com-
monly supposed, they were not yet to seeke of a c
o
pet
e
t meanes
to gratifie her M
ty
. And if they should not by somewhat shewe
their thanckfulnesse unto her, I doubted of
e sequele in re-
garde of her displeasure. But w
at
soever I could alleage,
they were wonderfull vehem
e
t in all their
testations,
t
they were desitute of meanes to satisfie her H
es
and
t
they
could not yealde unto her, not onely
t
summe of a hundred
thousand poundes, w
c
your L. doth require to be payed every
yeare, but not a farre lesser summe, w
t
out incurring
e perill
of their utter confusion. And where they understood
t
I meant to convey her answear to her M
ty
and not to carrie
it my selfe, as they had imagined, I would, soone after it was
delivered in writing unto me, they sent of purpose to calle me
into their publicke assembly, and there they intreated or rather
[c
o
jured] me (they spake w
t
such affection)
t
in a matter of
t
fol.289v
mom
e
t whereon so much depended for her M
ies
goods as well as
theirs, I would take
e paynes my selfe to returne w
t
their
a
swear
and laye before her M
tie
not onely those reasons w
c
advaunce
her demaunde, but sithe I know in like maner how to stoode
w
t
these c
o
tries, acquaint her also of my selfe directly w
t
e
full estate of their affaires, and
t
in every particular, w
c
could
not be ex
p
ssed to be
fectly conceaved but by verball dem
o
stration,
w
c
would cause her, they were certaine, to runne some other course,
then such as might occasion
e flatte subversion of
e c
o
trey. They
would have willingly s
e
t some Deputie of their owne, but
t
it could
not be done w
t
out writing to
e Provinces, w
c
would make but a
long worke, and was not so c
o
venient. Having made my excuse
for diverse causes, but chiefly for want of her M
es
licence, they urged
me so earnestly, and promised me to write so effectually unto
her, as I should not neede to doubte but
t
it would be well
c
o
strued. At w
c
their inst
a
t desire, because I doe consider,
t
heere I can doe little, till I see how her H
es
will
ceede upon their
answear, and
t
I may at her pleasure returne againe assoone as any
mess enger, I have thought it fitter for her service, not to stand upo[n]
denyall. But
t
w
c
moveth me most unto it, is an overture mad[e]
unto me in privat c
o
munication by a Deputy of Holland, w
c
whether it
ceede fr
o
e partie alone, or w
t
some notice of
e States, I am not well
assured. For he
testeth unto me w
t
earnest assertion
t he doeth
it altogether w
t
out
e privity of his collegues, and although I doe beleve
it, yet I can not but c
o
jecture,
t
somew
at
hath bin spoken in
e meeting
among them, wherby he hath good knowledge how
e rest are affe-
cted and doth direct himselfe thereafter. His drifte in this
overture is so to
portion her M
es
demande w
t
e c
o
treis ability, as
it may be brought to passe w
t
e liking of
e inhabit
a
ts, and both be
very honorable and beneficial to her M
tie
. Because
e matter is
but rawely imparted, and hath many pointes in it to be duely con-
sidered, it may happily hold me heere some 7 or 8 dayes, before I
take my voyage. I have sent
e meane while their answear before
w
t
their l
re
s to her M
ty
and
e
LL. of
e Councell
, of w
c
one doeth
c
o
cerne
S
r
Horatio Pallavicines
debt, wherein w
at
soever hath beene
further said unto me, then their writing hath declared, I will
signifie at my c
o
ming.
